lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'

* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.
* A GUI for Duke using FXML.
* Controller for MainWindow. Provides the layout for the other controls.
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
* A Parser object which validates the input by the user.
* Parses a given input into 2 parts, mainly the keyword and the task description.

* @return The given input split into keyword at index 0 and the task at index 1

* @param input The task description that is retrieve from the user input
* @return The index of the task that is required
protected void checkValidArgLength(String[] input) throws DukeEmptyException {
* A Storage object that deals with loading and saving tasks. Whenever the task list updates, {@code saveToDisk} will be
* executed and the new task will be saved into disk. Whenever the bot starts, {@code loadFromDisk} will be executed
* and load all the tasks that were previously saved into the Chatbot.
private static final DateTimeFormatter DATE_TIME_FORMATTER = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("dd/MM/yyyy HH:mm");

* Saves the given list of tasks into the disk.
* @param tasks An ArrayList of type Task that consists of all the given tasks that were previously saved.
System.out.println("SoCCat cannot recognise the type of this task and will not save it into disk.");

* Displays a farewell message to the user.
return "Goodbye! SoCCat wishes to see you again soon!";

return "Here are the tasks in your list: " + "\n" + allTasks;
return "Here are the matching tasks in your list: " + "\n" + allTasks;

* @param size the total number of tasks in the task list

return "Now you have " + size + (size < 2 ? " task" : " tasks") + " in your list.";

* A Deadline object that is a type of Task, but contains the date and time on top of the task description.
* Returns the LocalDateTime of this Deadline instance.
* @return the datetime information of this {@code Deadline}
* A Event object that is a type of Task, but contains the date and time on top of the task description.

* @param duration the datetime of the event
* Returns the LocalDateTime of this Event instance.
* @return the datetime information of this {@code Event}
* A Task object that the user inputs into the Chatbot. The Task contains a description of it and could be either
* {@code markAsDone()} to indicate it is completed or {@code unmarkAsNotDone()} to indicate it is not completed.
protected static final DateTimeFormatter DATE_TIME_FORMATTER = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy hh:mm a");

return "Nice! I've marked this task as done: \n" + this;
* Returns a string that states the given task is unmarked and not done.
